sentence_samples.speaker: bitbythecron
sentence_samples.sentence: hi everyone (hopefully) quick question. my understanding (please keep me honest!) is that in DL4J (and most other ML/DL frameworks), all of a particular neural network's configurations (layers, weights, misc parameters) are just data configurations, and as such, can be saved to disk in a file. that way, I can tune a network to work exactly how I want it, store its configs/settings in a file, and then reload that file at a later time to reproduce the exact same network later on. if this is true (and correct me if its not!) then it occurred to me that it would be super helpful if these "network config files" had a standard format. that way, I could train a network to learn how to spot a bowling ball in an image using one framework/language/API, export the file, and use it down the road in another project that perhaps uses a totally different tech stack. but because both frameworks support this open standard, both would be capable of loading and configuring the exact same neural network that will correctly identify "bowling balls" in an image. does such a standard file format exist, and does DL4J support it? thanks! ONNX perhaps?e

sentence_samples.speaker: wmeddie
sentence_samples.sentence: ONNX is the closest thing out there to a universal format. But it doesn’t support everything.e

sentence_samples.speaker: bitbythecron
sentence_samples.sentence: Thanks @wmeddie , googling DL4J + ONNX I see some evidence of support for it in DL4J but its mostly just javadocs that pop up. do you know if DL4J allows for ONNX-based exports, and if so, how comprehensive/developed that feature is?e

sentence_samples.speaker: wmeddie
sentence_samples.sentence: Not sure if we have export yet. But import is coming.e

sentence_samples.speaker: bitbythecron
sentence_samples.sentence: Thanks, and finally: is it fair to say that DL4J stores more network features/params/settings/etc. in its own serialization mechanism than what ONNX currently supports?e

sentence_samples.speaker: wmeddie
sentence_samples.sentence: Hard to say... ONNX does support quite a lot of ops right now. I’m pretty sure SameDiff has more ops than ONNX supports, but for the high level layers in DL4J... I would guess it has them all.e

sentence_samples.speaker: bitbythecron
sentence_samples.sentence: ahh, SameDiff is what DL4J uses then?e

sentence_samples.speaker: ZagButNoZig
sentence_samples.sentence: Does Dl4j automatically clear unused nd arrays? Because I am working on a genetic algorithm which runs multiple networks at the same time for multiple generations and after a few runs i get a out of memory exception? Or is it just the networks overflowing the memory?emmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: AlexDBlack
sentence_samples.sentence: @ZagButNoZig DL4J uses (by default) a workspace memory management strategy. we're not reliant on garbage collection or anything for the activations/gradients (forward/backward pass). so memory use should be flat during training and inference but we are reliant on garbage collection to clean up any network parameters memory (and workspace memory) for networks you've finished with (and have cleared all references to so they can be garbage collected)emmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: ZagButNoZig
sentence_samples.sentence: Is there a way to make networks more "lightweight" because in a GA having multiple gigabytes of memory per network is quite heavy. The network only has 124 params.emmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: AlexDBlack
sentence_samples.sentence: @ZagButNoZig the only way you can get multiple GB of memory use from a tiny network is if you have huge activations (like CNN with like 1000x1000 images or whatever) or huge minibatch sizeemmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: ZagButNoZig
sentence_samples.sentence: @AlexDBlack I have one network / thread getting fed a 3 x 5 x 5 per game step. Anything suspicious ? Because they get fed a lot of data but not at the same time. And I am at 4.8 GB of memoryemmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: AlexDBlack
sentence_samples.sentence: and you're sure you are not leaking array references somewhere, or have loaded multiple GB into memory? even if it was somehow from the network (detached arrays - i.e., those not in workspaces) it would be cleaned up by garbage collector. you can check memory use using [<-CODE->] method too, might show you something usefulemmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: ZagButNoZig
sentence_samples.sentence: To get the 3x5x5 gamestate i generate 3 5x5 double arrays then I create 3 ND-Arrays from those double arrays and stack them onto eachother using vstack to then reshape them into one (1x)3x5x5 ND-Array. Does this leak ref.? If so whats a better way of doing that?emmmmm

sentence_samples.speaker: AlexDBlack
sentence_samples.sentence: that sounds OK. by "leaking array references" I mean you have something (like a list, map, etc) that stores lots of arrays permanently so they can't be garbage collected. if you can't work it out, feel free to open an !issue (with a reproducible example we can run) and we'll take a look when we have timeemmmmm
